newsitem.title: FRANCE: Canal+, SECA file complaint against Spain.
newsitem.headline: Canal+, SECA file complaint against Spain.

text.p: French pay television company Canal Plus and Franco-German firm SECA have filed a complaint with the European Commission accusing Spain of breaching European trade rules, Canal Plus said on Thursday.

"By refusing to approve the decoders used by Canal Satelite Digital, the Spanish Telecommunications Market Commission has prevented the sale of decoders already marketed in other European countries...and is preventing Canal Plus and SECA from freely conducting their business as digital technology suppliers in Spain. This constitutes a direct breach of free trade and provision of services within the European Union," the company said.

"Canal Plus and SECA consider that the Spanish Commission's decision causes them very serious financial and commercial damage, given the sizeable investments they have made to develop and promote worldwide the Mediaguard access control system and Mediahighway interactive system," Canal Plus said in a statement.

It said the Spanish Commission refused last month to register Canal Satelite Digital as a digital TV access control operator, alleging it did not have sufficient guarantees on compliance with technical criteria defined by Spanish law.

"Both companies stress that the Mediaguard and Mediahighway systems fully abide by all European regulations on digital TV and comply with the Digital Video Broadcast recommendations," Canal Plus said.
SECA is owned in equal parts by Canal Plus and German media group Bertelsmann.
